awd_titl_txt: Conference: Biodesign Symposium: How to Grow a Biodesigner
awd_abstract_narration:
This project aims to serve the national interest by helping to prepare students to enter the biodesign workforce of the future. Biodesign centers recently have sprung up at a variety of institutions across the country. These centers focus on creative approaches to human healthcare and basic science, incorporating the viewpoints of fields as diverse as biology, engineering, art, and computer science. The multidisciplinary and interdisciplinary nature of the field suggests an openness to individuals with a variety of backgrounds, not just those versed in traditional STEM fields. The Biodesign Symposium is poised to address how to educate undergraduate students to enter this complex, challenging, and exciting new field. Today's undergraduate students will contribute to the workforce of tomorrow, so defining the entry points and training needed to contribute to the future biodesign workforce is a timely endeavor.  

The Biodesign Symposium will be held at The New School in New York City on June 12, 2024. The symposium will convene formal and informal educators, community members, artists and designers, researchers, students, and industry representatives. Symposium topics include shaping lab-based and/or experimental activities to provide biotechnology instruction for undergraduate students without formal science backgrounds, strategies for incorporating place-based and identity-based models in biotechnology instruction, case studies on grounding biodesign learning in community engagement, strategies for aligning classroom instruction with industry needs, and methods for cross-disciplinary instruction in highly siloed institutional environments. The symposium intends to formalize academic practices and standardize learning outcomes for biodesign education. The NSF IUSE: EDU Program supports research and development projects to improve the effectiveness of STEM education for all students.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The Biodesign Symposium: How to Grow a Biodesigner is an annual, free conference-style event where educators, researchers, and practitioners of biodesign discuss their methods, observations, and recommendations for the integration of biodesign into undergraduate STEM education. Biodesign is an emerging field at the intersection of biology, technology, art, and design. Individuals, schools, and studios around the world engage in biodesign research and innovation to move toward the production of more sustainable futures for humans and our planet. Each year, presenters at the Symposium share ways of formalizing biodesign education and aligning biodesign learning outcomes with workplace needs.


The Symposium is a new initiative of the grantee institution, Biodesign Challenge (BDC). Founded in 2015, BDC is an international education nonprofit that asks students to envision, create, and critique the future of biotechnology. Participating students tackle some of the biggest problems we face today, including worldwide challenges in healthcare, sustainability, and climate justice. Alumni of BDC have gone on to build multi-million dollar biomaterials companies, show their bioart work in museums and galleries around the world, and become leaders in the sustainability space. While the Challenge primarily focuses on and supports student work, the Biodesign Symposium highlights educators, practitioners, and researchers. It provides a platform for these individuals to publish and share their work within the wider biodesign discipline. These contributions have improved, expanded, and legitimized biodesign education for undergraduate students by recommending best practices in academia and highlighting relevant career pathways.


NSF supported the inaugural Biodesign Symposium in June 2024. As part of this project, Biodesign Challenge partnered with Cambridge University Press & Assessment (CUP) to publish a Call for Proposals around the question, “How do we grow a biodesigner?” Over 70 papers and portfolios were reviewed for the publication, 68 were accepted by CUP’s Research Directions: Biotechnology Design journal, and 15 were chosen to present at the Symposium. 


The Symposium was held at Parsons School of Design in New York City on June 12, 2024. The day consisted of paper presentations that focused on research and practice around biodesign as well as break out discussion sessions convened around the paper topics.

 

Research presented at the Symposium addressed topics such as teaching biology and design in rural areas of America, building bio-based makerspaces in design schools, and the history of Indigenous biology. Two world-renowned biodesigners served as opening and closing keynote speakers, highlighting their field-building contributions as well as their teaching practices within biodesign.  


An 86-page proceedings document was published to encapsulate the disciplinary contributions of the Symposium. Links to the livestream, each author’s paper, and each breakout session group’s notes are all included in the proceedings. Because this was the first annual Symposium, this year was viewed as a survey of the field to better understand the priorities and needs of biodesign practitioners and educators. The PI and grantee institution aim to continue this conference with more targeted subject matter and calls to action in future years.
